description.narrative: RIWPS will implement a public campaign to create on national level, awareness, dialogue and promote efforts to adress some of the structural barriers that female police are facing in integrating themselves into the Afghan National Police. Also the publicstigma ofwomen police will be adressed. This project is a pilot activity with national coverage, and will aim to find the best approaches that will work in the long run to improve the situation and conditions for the female police inside and outside thegovernmental system.

participating-org.narrative: Research institute for women peace & security (RIWPS)

The Institute for Women Peace <(>&<)> Security # Afghanistan (registered with MoE)
RIWPS is a woman-led initiative conceptualized following the Peace Consultative Jirga in 2010 and established in 2011 to focus on increasing women#s inclusion and leadership in the effort to bring peace and security to Afghanistan. RIWPS seeks to build on and strengthen the advocacy campaigns carried out by many other women#s organizations in Kabul to ensure a coordinated and collaborative effort. The unique aspiration of theInstitute is to engage Afghan women and advance their strategic participation to improve social cohesion, restore war-torn communities, and rebuild relationships at the grassroots and national levels.
The rationale for the establishment of RIWPS is theoverall belief that Afghan women at the grassroots and community levels have important contributions to make to stability and peace, both in their traditional and emerging roles. Those contributions need to be documented and promoted for local and national peace <(>&<)> security efforts to be sustainable. RIWPS will document those contributions of women leaders at the grassroots, empower them with community mobilization and advocacy efforts and connect them to find and negotiate their spaces at the local governance structures as well as national governance structures.
Vision: To advance a new paradigm for peace and security in Afghanistan that is inclusive of women#s perspectives.
Mission: To leverage the knowledge of women leaders in grassroots movements, strengthen capacities, and support research thatwill increase women#s security and the gender-responsiveness of peace building policies, programs and institutions.
Strategic Approach: Research <(>&<)> evidence building on women#s contributions to peace <(>&<)>security; Advocacy through knowledge sharing; Training <(>&<)> empowerment; coordination with WPS stakeholders.
Summary of RIWPS activities since inception:
# Sexual and gender-based violence sensitization and tracking capacity building for public healthpractitioners in the Ministry of Public Health <(>&<)> HPIC (April-June 2012)
# Facilitation <(>&<)> editing of National Strategy for Inclusive Peace with Afghanistan Civil Society Network for Peace, in partnership with Oxfam GB (June 2012): RIWPS worked with ACSONP Members and solicited their inputs and perspective around CSOs role in community based peace building that formed the National Strategy.
# Capacity building <(>&<)> mobilization of female PPCs for women's inclusion in peace <(>&<)> reintegration for the femalemembers of the Provincial Peace Councils (July # December2012): RIWPS worked with HPC and PPCs in 25 provinces and mobilized around 50 female members of PPC to influence the provincial level reintegration processes.
# Evidence Building <(>&<)> research onwomen's rights and human rights abuses by the Afghan Local Police (ALP) in Kunduz <(>&<)> surrounding provinces (July-December 2012)
# Review <(>&<)> editing of the Women's Guide to Security Sector Reform from Afghanistan women's rights perspective <(>&<)> RIWPS experience with The Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of the Armed Forces (DCAF) and The Institute for Inclusive Security (July-August 2012)
# Research brief produced based on focus group discussions and activist interviews on Afghan women <(>&<)> the security transition in Afghanistan, published with International Civil Society Action Network following a consultation process with over 30 women organizations all around the country (Aug-December 2012)
# Conducted people#s perceptions survey commissioned by USIP in partnership with Institute of Rethinking Policies on the OpinionLeaders perspectives around peace and reconciliation process (July # September 2012)
# Conducted a baseline study on EVAW through a participatory action research on the implementation of Elimination of Violence against Women Law in 4 provinces including Kabul, Hirat, Balkh and Helmand. (December 2012-April 2013)
# Civil Society Dialogue with HPC on Roadmap: RIWPS has been collecting inputs and perspectives of communities, traditional and emerging leaders on the Peace Roadmap and started sharing with the HPC through a series of ongoing Dialogue sessions. (April # December 2013)
Currently RIWPS-Afghanistan is working with local CSOs on community-based inclusive peace building interventions. One of the key programs is RIWPS#s partnership with Oxfam-GB that is working with 3 other local CSOs on an inclusive peace building strategy <(>&<)> Provincial Peace Hearings on creating Regional and national mobilization of youth, elders, media sector and ulema groups around a common vision for sustainable peace process.
